entry.title: Mapping Internet Quality Across America with the Internet Innovation Initiative

link.title: Mapping Internet Quality Across America with the Internet Innovation Initiative

entry.content:
Overview

The Internet Innovation Initiative’s work in broadband measurement continues through collaboration with the University of Chicago Data Science Institute’s Data Science Clinic. Three students completed research addressing broadband policy challenges affecting universal internet access in the United States.

Key Points

Broadband measurement is at the heart of our project. The Internet Innovation Initiative leverages edge computing and hardware advances to enhance broadband measurement for research and policy applications while reducing deployment complexity and costs.

The Data Science Clinic students’ presentation examines the complexities of broadband policy in the United States and underscores the necessity for improved broadband data to identify infrastructure gaps more effectively.

The research identifies a critical need for better broadband performance data to support infrastructure investment decisions.

Funding

The Internet Innovation Initiative receives support through a National Science Foundation grant (Award No. 2213821 - CCRI CISE).

This research is part of the Internet Innovation Initiative at the University of Chicago.
entry.summary: Data Science Clinic students examine the complexities of broadband policy in the United States.

entry.title: Case Study: Collaboration with Greater Englewood Chamber of Commerce to Address Digital Inequity

link.title: Case Study: Collaboration with Greater Englewood Chamber of Commerce to Address Digital Inequity

entry.content:
Overview

The Internet Innovation Initiative partnered with the Greater Englewood Chamber of Commerce to address digital inequity on Chicago’s South Side. The collaboration emerged from a paradox: while fiber optic infrastructure existed beneath Englewood’s streets, major internet service providers refused to activate it without guaranteed full-price subscriptions from residents.

Key Challenge

The community needed empirical evidence to advocate for change beyond anecdotal complaints about slow speeds and unreliable connections.

Solution Implemented

The Internet Innovation Initiative distributed speedtester devices to local business owners, enabling measurement of actual internet performance across the neighborhood. This data collection effort aimed to build a localized map of internet quality issues.

The Initiative’s Role

The project leveraged the Internet Innovation Initiative’s infrastructure to:

  • Measure connectivity reality
  • Gather performance evidence
  • Empower community advocacy through data-driven insights

Next Steps

The partnership plans to expand device deployment to create comprehensive documentation of Englewood’s internet landscape, supporting sustained advocacy campaigns for improved infrastructure access.

This case demonstrates how technology-guided community engagement can illuminate hidden inequities and catalyze meaningful change.

This research is part of the Internet Innovation Initiative at the University of Chicago.
entry.summary: How community partnerships and data collection can illuminate hidden inequities and catalyze meaningful change.

entry.title: Case Study: IPv4 vs. IPv6 Internet Speed Analysis

link.title: Case Study: IPv4 vs. IPv6 Internet Speed Analysis

entry.content:
By Amanda Hsu, Georgia Institute of Technology

IPv6 adoption statistics showing growth over time.

Overview

This case study examines how Internet speed differs between IPv4 and IPv6 protocols using the Internet Innovation Initiative research platform. The researcher investigates whether connection speeds vary depending on which protocol users employ.

Background on IP Addressing

IPv4 addresses, limited to 32 bits (approximately 4 billion addresses), became exhausted in 2019. IPv6, with 128 bits, provides vastly more addresses—over 340 trillion trillion trillion unique addresses.

Current Adoption

Google reports that over 47% of its users connect via IPv6, reflecting steady growth over two decades.

Research Questions

The investigation seeks to answer:

  • Does IPv4 or IPv6 affect user speeds?
  • How do standard speed tests like Ookla and NDT7 differ between protocols?
  • Do speed variations stem from different network paths or router processing differences?
Comparison of IPv4 and IPv6 performance measurements.

Preliminary Findings

Early measurements suggest the two protocols degrade in speed under different conditions, with IPv4 slowdowns not necessarily affecting IPv6 speeds simultaneously. Performance variations correlate with Internet Service Provider operations.

Broader Impact

Understanding IPv4/IPv6 performance differences could improve broadband coverage analysis used for FCC policy decisions regarding underserved communities.

This research is part of the Internet Innovation Initiative at the University of Chicago.
entry.summary: Examining how Internet speed differs between IPv4 and IPv6 protocols using the Internet Innovation Initiative research platform.

entry.title: Is Your WiFi Limiting Your Home Internet Performance?

link.title: Is Your WiFi Limiting Your Home Internet Performance?

entry.content:
By Antonia Sanhueza and Marc Richardson, with feedback from Tarun Mangla, Kyle MacMillan, Nicole Marwell, and Nick Feamster

Overview

This data story examines whether upgrading your internet service plan guarantees improved performance when using WiFi connections. The research analyzes data from Netrics devices deployed in Chicago households to explore how WiFi setups can result in slower speeds than the access connection supports.

WiFi connection diagram showing the difference between access speed and WiFi speed.

Key Finding

WiFi bottlenecks—situations where wireless speeds fall below wired access speeds—are widespread. The analysis reveals that 89 percent of studied households experienced at least one WiFi bottleneck during the analysis period.

Distribution of WiFi bottlenecks across households.

Main Insights

Prevalence by Speed Tier: Households subscribing to high-speed plans (200+ Mbps) experience significantly more WiFi bottlenecks than those with lower-tier plans. Among frequent bottleneck-experiencers, median access speed reached 686 Mbps, compared to 57 Mbps for those rarely experiencing bottlenecks.

Performance Gap: In the 800+ Mbps tier, the gap between purchased access speeds and actual experienced speeds reached 609 Mbps due to WiFi limitations.

Recommendations for Consumers

The analysis suggests upgrading your router, relocating it for better coverage, or installing WiFi extenders may be more cost-effective than purchasing higher service tiers if WiFi is your bottleneck.

Policy Implications

Infrastructure investments alone won’t improve community internet equity without complementary policies providing appropriate WiFi equipment to households.

This research is part of the Internet Innovation Initiative at the University of Chicago.
entry.summary: WiFi bottlenecks are widespread - 89 percent of studied households experienced at least one during our analysis.

entry.title: Understanding Chicago’s Digital Divide: What Does Census Data Tell Us?

link.title: Understanding Chicago’s Digital Divide: What Does Census Data Tell Us?

entry.content:
Overview

A research partnership between the Data Science Institute, a Data Science Clinic team, and the City of Chicago examined internet access disparities across Chicago’s 77 community areas using U.S. Census Bureau data. The study aimed to identify neighborhoods with the lowest connectivity and understand how socioeconomic factors influence internet adoption.

Key Findings

Geographic Disparities: The analysis revealed that roughly 80 percent of Chicago households are connected to the Internet, but deep disparities in availability and adoption exist at the neighborhood level. The least-connected neighborhoods cluster on Chicago’s South and West Sides, with Englewood, West Englewood, Fuller Park, and North Lawndale experiencing internet access rates between 57-60%, compared to 91% in Lakeview and Near South Side.

Socioeconomic Correlations: Research identified strong connections between internet access and multiple demographic factors. Community areas with higher hardship scores—measuring crowded housing, poverty, unemployment, education gaps, dependency, and low per capita income—consistently showed lower connectivity rates.

Most Influential Factors: Statistical analysis of individual-level data revealed that Internet access is most strongly correlated with household income and education. Households with elderly residents showed notably lower internet access, while Black and Hispanic populations faced greater connectivity barriers compared to White and Asian populations.

Policy Recommendations

The researchers advocate for three approaches:

  • Expanding affordability programs like Chicago Connected
  • Developing community networks in underserved areas
  • Providing digital literacy education, particularly for older populations

This research is part of the Internet Innovation Initiative at the University of Chicago.
entry.summary: Examining internet access disparities across Chicago's 77 community areas using U.S. Census Bureau data.

entry.title: A Tale of Two Gigs
entry.content:
By Marc Richardson

Summary

This data story examines whether households subscribing to identical internet service plans from the same provider experience comparable performance across different Chicago neighborhoods.

Key Findings

The research compared two households in Hyde Park and South Shore, both paying for Gigabit internet from Xfinity. The results revealed significant disparities: the Hyde Park household experienced higher-quality Internet than the South Shore household. Specific performance gaps included approximately 100 Mbps higher download speeds in Hyde Park and consistently lower latency measurements.

Main Arguments

Limitations of Existing Data: Crowdsourced datasets like Ookla Speedtest suffer from sampling bias, concentrating measurements in wealthier neighborhoods while missing underserved communities. Additionally, these tests often measure WiFi performance rather than actual ISP-delivered speeds, creating distorted pictures of connection quality.

The Netrics Solution: The University of Chicago developed Netrics, a measurement platform providing continuous, household-level internet performance data. Unlike sporadic user-initiated tests, Netrics devices measure connections directly to a home’s source of internet and run multiple tests daily.

Conclusion

Achieving true digital equity requires monitoring not just internet availability but also performance quality across communities, necessitating continuous, fine-grained data on Internet performance.

This research is part of the Internet Innovation Initiative at the University of Chicago.
entry.summary: Do households with identical internet plans experience comparable performance across different neighborhoods?

entry.title: How Much Internet Does Video Conferencing Need?

link.title: How Much Internet Does Video Conferencing Need?

entry.content:
By Kyle MacMillan, Tarun Mangla, James Saxon, and Nick Feamster

Overview

Researchers at the University of Chicago’s Internet Innovation Initiative conducted laboratory experiments to determine bandwidth requirements for popular video conferencing applications during the COVID-19 pandemic. The City of Chicago commissioned this study to help identify households lacking sufficient internet connectivity.

Key Findings

Single Call Performance: The three most-tested applications—Zoom, Google Meet, and Microsoft Teams—required approximately 1-2 Mbps download and 0.75-1.4 Mbps upload speeds for individual calls. Most residential Internet plans provide plenty of capacity to handle this usage, with the FCC’s broadband standard of 25 Mbps download and 3 Mbps upload far exceeding typical needs.

Multiple Simultaneous Calls: Problems emerge when multiple video conferences run simultaneously. The upload limits can come into play with only 2 simultaneous Teams meetings or 3-4 concurrent Zoom or Meet sessions, creating competition for bandwidth. Applications sometimes prioritize certain calls, degrading quality for others.

Meeting Size Impact: Larger meetings with participants using speaker mode increased bandwidth demands, particularly stressing upload capacity on minimum-speed plans.

Service Interruptions: When bandwidth dropped for 30 seconds, apps required 25 to 50 seconds to return to their pre-interruption performance.

Policy Implications

Rather than relying solely on FCC broadband definitions, policymakers should establish household-level benchmarks addressing realistic usage scenarios—such as supporting multiple simultaneous remote school participants or work-from-home situations.

This research is part of the Internet Innovation Initiative at the University of Chicago.
entry.summary: Laboratory experiments reveal the bandwidth requirements for Zoom, Google Meet, and Microsoft Teams.
